poem:
Saginaw Voices  

In union halls, whispers stir—  
Lopez, hearts swayed by resolve,  
urges daughters to carve their mark,  
on paper ballots—silent power.  
In the heart of Saginaw's pulse,  
their votes weave threads of change,  
against iron walls of imposers—  
a chorus of quiet defiance sings.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Your vote does matter’: Latino and Black leaders in Saginaw make a final push for Harris Alice Lopez left the union hall so disturbed by what she had just heard that she determined she would persuade her daughters to vote even though they had never done so before. A friend had taken Lopez to a meeting arranged by Latino community leaders in bellwether Saginaw county, Michigan, to discuss Project 2025, the authoritarian plan to impose". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
